title: Florida students walk out of class at Monarch High School to support principal and other leaders who were suspended for letting trans volleyball player play on all girl team
body_text:
Florida students walk out of class at Monarch High School to support principal and other leaders who were suspended for letting trans volleyball player play on all girls' team
- Students at Monarch High School waved signs and chanted in support of their classmate and school staff
- Principal James Cecil and four other members of staff were reassigned amid an ongoing investigation
- Under state law, transgender girls and women are not allowed to play on girls' and women's sports teams at public schools
Hundreds of Florida high schoolers staged a walkout this week after their principal and other staffers were reassigned over a transgender student's participation on the girls' volleyball team.
Students at Monarch High School packed onto the football field Tuesday, waving signs in support of their peers and chanting 'trans lives matter.'
The demonstration was followed by another on Wednesday.
The first protest came a day after principal James Cecil and three other staffers - assistant principal Kenneth May, athletic director Dione Hester and volleyball coach Jessica Norton - were moved to' non-school sites.' Temporary athletic coach Alex Burgess was also told that his services would be put on hold.
An investigation into the decision to allow the trans member to compete is under investigation. State law requires athletic participants to compete in their biological gender.
A spokesperson for Broward County Public Schools said Cecil and the other staffers were reassigned 'pending the outcome of an investigation into allegations of improper student participation in sports.'
Hundreds of students at Monarch High School in Coconut Creek, Florida, flooded the football field in back-to-back demonstrations to support their school principal
The teens waved signs in support of school staff and chanted 'trans lives matter'
'I think this has completely ruined her life,' team captain Jordan Campbell said of the unnamed student.
'I played with her and I think everyone who thinks that they have this opinion on her but don’t even know her, have no idea who she is. She was the sweetest person anyone has ever met.'
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signed a law in 2021 excluding transgender girls and women from girls' and women’s sports teams in public schools.
'In Florida, girls are going to play girls sports and boys are going to play boys sports,' DeSantis said as he signed the bill into law. 'We're going to make sure that that's the reality.'
The statute says athletic teams or sports designated for females, women or girls are not open to male students.
It adds that 'a statement of a student’s biological sex on the student’s official birth certificate is considered to have correctly stated the student’s biological sex at birth.'
More than 20 other states have similarly restrictive laws including Kansas, North Dakota and Wyoming.
The district’s superintendent, Peter Licata, maintained that the reassignment was 'not an indication of discipline' and added: 'Again, we want to make sure we do this right, nobody is guilty of anything at this point.'
Tuesday's demonstration came one day after members of staff were moved to 'non-school sites' amid an investigation into a transgender student playing on the girls' volleyball team
Students rallied behind their principal, James Cecil (pictured), and four other staffers who were reassigned following 'allegations of improper student participation in sports'
The participation of transgender girls and women on girls' and women's public school sports teams is banned under Florida state law
At a Tuesday press conference, Licata told reporters there would be 'new processes' for athlete eligibility going forward.
'We’ll have an extra level of investigation on making sure everyone is eligible for the sport they’re playing, in all aspects, grade level, grades, so forth and so on,' he said.
But Campbell expressed concern about her teammate, who has been missing from school.
'Right now she’s not being treated like a human, she’s not being treated like she’s worth anything to anyone,' Campbell told NBC6.
'The things people are saying in school and on social media is beyond disgusting. She’s a human and deserves to be treated like one, how about we bring fairness into that? 'Cause she’s not being treated like that right now.'
The transgender student appears to be the plaintiff in a June 2021 lawsuit filed against the governor, the School Board of Broward County and other state officials.
At the time, the student - identified only by the initials D.N. - was 13 years old and intended to try out for the school’s volleyball team.
'The Florida legislation that is the subject of this complaint, SB 1028, would prevent D.N. from participating in the sports she loves and decimate her social network,' the suit read, in part.
Superintendent Peter Licata said the reassignment was 'not an indication of discipline' and added that 'nobody is guilty of anything at this point'
'This statute, which is part of a wave of anti-transgender bills across the county, would stigmatize this teenager and separate her from her peers and teammates.'
A federal judge rejected the suit earlier this month, and Licata claimed he was unaware of its existence when questioned.
School district spokesman John Sullivan issued a statement saying the district was committed to following state law and would take 'appropriate action' following the outcome of the investigation.
'We are committed to providing all our students with a safe and inclusive learning environment,' Sullivan added.
The state Department of Education was adamant in its stance. 'Under Governor DeSantis, boys will never be allowed to play girls’ sports. It’s that simple,' a spokesperson said.
'As soon as the Department was notified that a biological male was playing on a girls’ team in Broward County, we instructed the district to take immediate action since this is a direct violation of Florida law.'
The spokesperson expressed hope that 'those responsible' face 'serious consequences.'
